trial_identification.studytitle: The Positive Outlook Study: a randomised controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of an online self management program for men living with HIV
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of 'Positive Outlook', an online self management program for men living with HIV on improving health related outcomes as measured by the heiQ compared to usual care control.

interventions.interventions: Positive Outlook is a 7 week group self management program for men living with HIV. The program is delivered via a website. Participants will be required to log on to the program for at least 90minutes per week and complete relevant modules, activities and contribute to discussion boards. The intervention is guided by the theoretical framework of self management theory and self efficacy theory.
interventions.comparator: Usual care: Participants will continue with their usual doctors appointments and any extra counselling or other supports they may be receiving.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 1: outcomes of health education as assessed by the heiQ
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 2: domain specific self efficacy as assessed by a survey specifically designed for this study
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 3: quality of life as assessed by the PROQOL-HIV
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: General health and quality of life as measured by the SF12
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression as measured by the Depression Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS21)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Social support as measured by the Duke Social Support Index (DSSI)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self efficacy as measured by the Generalised Self Efficacy Scale (GSE)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Adjustment to HIV as measured by the Mental Adjustment to HIV Scale (MAH)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, immediately after intervention completion and at 12 week follow up.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: HIV positive (self report) Over 18 years old Male Self identifies as gay or MSM (men who have sex with men) Ability to independently access a computer and use the internet for at least 90minutes per week for 7 weeks Ability to read, write and understand English

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be enrolled once pre test questionnaires have been returned and allocated to either the intervention or control group by computerised central randomisation.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table generated by computer software.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is aimed at evaluating the efficacy of an online self management program for men living with HIV in Australia. Positive outlook is a 7 week online group self management program for men living with HIV. Participants will be asked to log onto the program for approximately 90minutes per week and complete modules, activities and contribute to various discussion boards. The program focuses on the management of physical, social and emotional aspects of living with HIV. Positive Outlook provides participants the opportunity to develop skills for the management of HIV within their daily lives. The group model allows participants to share experiences and to learn from each other. Particular attention is payed to disclosure of HIV and the management of HIV within intimate relationships. We hypothesise that intervention group participants will demonstrate improvements in self efficacy, outcomes of health education, adjustment to HIV, depression anxiety and stress, quality of life and social support compared to control participants at follow up and 12 week follow up.
